image.altText: A black and white camera image of a driver holding a phone in one hand and pulling a finger with the other

props.synopsis: Three drivers are expected to lose their licences after being caught by South Australia's new mobile phone detection cameras at least five times each in a single week, with 2,500 fines issued after a grace period ended.

title.children: Drivers fined 2,500 times in week of mobile phone detections, with three expected to lose licences

image.altText: GettyImages-2177201442

props.synopsis: Socceroos player Riley McGree says the team is embracing the pressure it faces a crucial World Cup qualifying match against China.

title.children: 'Pressure is a privilege': Socceroos prepare for crucial clash against China with World Cup on the line

image.altText: A truck bogged in muddy red dirt.

props.synopsis: A remote West Australian community fears truck drivers will stop bringing supplies unless urgent upgrades are made to its "rough as guts" delivery route.

title.children: This outback road bogged five vehicles in a day and could soon leave a community stranded

image.altText: two smiling AFL footballers chatting after a game

props.synopsis: Thousands flocked to Port Lincoln over the weekend, for one of the state's biggest celebrations of Indigenous culture.

title.children: Eddie Betts and Tyson Stengle thrill crowds at SA's largest celebration of Indigenous footy culture

image.altText: a man in a suit with the photo showing his side profile

props.synopsis: David Speirs has announced he intends to quit parliament and pause his Liberal party membership, with police saying he has also been charged. What does this mean for his future and the electorate he represents?

title.children: From SA Liberal leader to arrest, how did it all unfold?

image.altText: Two go karts racing on a dirt track

props.synopsis: Racers and spectators flock to South Australia's south-east to compete in the Australian Dirt Kart Titles, with organisers saying the sport is a relatively affordable way to get into motor racing.

title.children: Australian Dirt Kart Titles organisers say sport is growing as grassroots introduction for juniors

image.altText: Assala Sayara speaks at Pro-Palestine rally.

props.synopsis: Protesters have gathered outside Federal Parliament to demand Australia sanction Israel for its actions in Gaza and Lebanon, a day after commemorations a year on from the Hamas terrorist attack on southern Israel.

title.children: 'We come with rage': Pro-Palestine protesters say ongoing conflict taking emotional toll on local community

image.altText: A glass office building exterior reflects other buildings.

props.synopsis: "They got away with it" is a common refrain after corporate scandals that end without consequences for individuals. A landmark High Court ruling could radically reshape that.

title.children: The court decision sending a chill through board rooms and executive suites

image.altText: Peter Dutton yelling in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: The opposition leader fiercely condemned the prime minister for using the motion for personal political gain and accused him of "talking out of both sides of his mouth".

title.children: Peter Dutton didn't support a motion marking the October 7 anniversary because of three lines

image.altText: a woman wearing a face mask walking in front of street art

props.synopsis: Australia has recorded its first cases of the XEC COVID-19 variant that has been spreading in Europe this year. Here's what you need to know about XEC — the highly transmissible strain that has been reported in 29 countries.

title.children: A highly transmissible COVID-19 variant has arrived in Australia. What you need to know about XEC

image.altText: Clayton Oliver walks off the field with his head down

props.synopsis: The Clayton Oliver story shows no signs of slowing down as day two of the AFL trade period continues to tick along. Follow live for the latest updates and confirmed moves.

title.children: Clayton Oliver trade 'not given up on' despite Melbourne's firm denials

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Clayton Oliver trade 'not given up on'
OFFICIAL: Jack Graham joins West Coast in free agency

image.altText: Timelapse of a sky from twilight to night, with antennas scattered across the landscape.

props.synopsis: If there are aliens out there, we'll find them. That's the message from the team behind one of the world's biggest science projects being built in remote Australia.

title.children: 'Are we alone in the universe?' This giant Australian project aims to find out

image.altText: A boulder on black.

props.synopsis: The European Space Agency's Hera will travel to the scene of the crash and investigate whether the asteroid has a new crater or new shape and whether it has begun to tumble.

title.children: NASA rammed an asteroid to see if they could change its course. It worked — but now they want to see the damage

image.altText: Hurricane Milton

props.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of residents in Florida's Tampa region are bracing for the second major hurricane in weeks, Milton set to make landfall as a category five storm on Wednesday.

title.children: What to know about 'explosively' intensifying Hurricane Milton as it speeds toward Florida

image.altText: Jacob Hersant, dressed in a white shirt and blue suit, photographed in dappled sunlight outdoors.

props.synopsis: White supremacist Jacob Hersant has become the first person found guilty of breaking a Victorian law that bans performing the Nazi salute in public.

title.children: Far-right extremist who challenged validity of Nazi salute ban becomes first Victorian to be found guilty of new offence

image.altText: Marley Wright-Martin wears a grey t-shirt and smiles at the camera in front of some bushes.

props.synopsis: Marley Wright-Martin, 27, was being held in solitary confinement at Port Phillip Prison when he died in September. His family has given permission for his name and image to be used.

title.children: 'We should all be outraged': Family of Aboriginal man who died in custody calls for answers

image.altText: The Israeli flag hanging from the frame of a house.

props.synopsis: One year ago, Hamas militants infiltrated Be'eri kibbutz. It was one of many coordinated attacks across Israel that began the Israel-Hamas war — and a delayed response by the Israeli defence force has been blamed for some of the 101 deaths, and dozens taken hostage.

title.children: Heroism, heartbreak and hundreds dead: Inside the Be'eri massacre

image.altText: Man sitting at board room table speaking to politicians

props.synopsis: The delivery of two new Spirit of Tasmania vessels has faced significant scrutiny over its repeated delays and cost blowouts. The former chair of the ferry operator has now taken aim at the government over its "appalling" support

title.children: Spirit of Tasmania saga escalates with claims of safety risks, 'appalling' support and strained relationships

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek holds a python at Parliament House

props.synopsis: Shortly after starting as minister, Tanya Plibersek laid out a plan to put the environment back on the national agenda. Two years on, as Australia hosts a global summit, Michael Slezak looks at how things have gone.

title.children: She said Australians 'voted for the environment' in 2022. Two years on, what's Tanya Plibersek been able to achieve?

image.altText: Kangaroo threatened by bushfire

props.synopsis: The group warns climate change will cause more regular and severe natural disasters that will overwhelm the ability of the federal government and its agencies to help protect and rebuild communities.

title.children: 'Unimaginable new extremes': Call for 'emergency mobilisation' to deal with climate change threats

image.altText: The flags of Iran and the United States of America behind a petrol pump.

props.synopsis: A day after oil prices surged, US President Joe Biden warned Israel against military strikes on Iran's oil export facilities for good reason — any attack could ignite another bout of inflation, and possibly plunge the world into recession.

title.children: How the Middle East could derail the global economy

image.altText: Rows of milk cartons lined up in a shop fridge

props.synopsis: There is currently no law requiring grocery stores to display visible pricing on their shelves, creating a legal loophole that leaves some shoppers "flying blind" when it comes to the weekly shop.

title.children: 'There would be outrage': Shoppers confused and frustrated by shops with no prices

image.altText: A man and a woman pose for a photograph on a beach foreshore.

props.synopsis: An election candidate's social media posts containing derogatory remarks about police have put the Queensland Labor Party into damage control, weeks out from the state election.

title.children: Queensland premier defends Labor candidate after revelations of anti-police social media posts

image.altText: A ute with a toolbox drives down a mainstreet surrounded by businesses.

props.synopsis: The 19-year-old Mansfield apprentice was inside the toolbox for more than 20 minutes while his director drove between jobs. The apprentice recorded a video commenting on the heat and his discomfort.

title.children: Plumber fined $20,000 after putting young apprentice in ute toolbox

image.altText: A man wearing a navy blue t-shirt and sunglasses speaks at a podium.

props.synopsis: US citizen Khaled Beydoun was a guest speaker at an October 7 rally held outside Lakemba mosque on Monday. Several hundred people gathered at the rally, where speakers criticised politicians for their stance.

title.children: US speaker's visa under review after saying October 7 a 'celebration' at pro-Palestinian rally

image.altText: A medium shot of a court house

props.synopsis: A 28-year-old man intended to destroy an ex-services club and burn some of the people inside when he allegedly poured fuel over two people in a small central New South Wales town, a court has been told.

title.children: Man doused bartender and pub patron in petrol during 'malicious' attack, court hears

image.altText: Christos Tsiolkas crosses his arms and stands at a pool in front of signage declaring "deep water".

props.synopsis: Christos Tsiolkas is one of Australia's most celebrated authors, but as a young man he nearly left the country after experiencing 'absolute euphoria' overseas.

title.children: 'I was wrong': The piece of writing that author Christos Tsiolkas regrets to this day

image.altText: Yvonne Stretton sits with Dr Kean-Seng Lim in his office.

props.synopsis: Data from the Royal Australian College of GPs shows doctors are spending longer with patients but are worried about their financial viability as more patients either delay or avoid making appointments.

title.children: Good GPs are 'invisible' but this doctor uses maths to measure success

image.altText: Banking apps appear on a phone screen

props.synopsis: Consumer groups are calling on the government to abandon parts of new draft scam laws, saying they are unworkable and put the onus of proof on victims seeking compensation.

title.children: Growing backlash over government's victim compo proposal in new draft scam laws

image.altText: AntonioMichell-4

props.synopsis: Antonio was a specialist trauma physio in Chile. In Australia, he has swept floors and driven rideshare for years waiting for recognition, despite a physio shortage.

title.children: 'We have doctors driving rideshare': Government urged to streamline overseas qualification schemes

image.altText: Bill Bailey stands with one hand raised, the other over his heart, singing joyfully in front of bank of keyboards

props.synopsis: One song reminds British comic Bill Bailey of a dear, departed friend. And the other he wants to be played at his funeral.

title.children: Bill Bailey on why one Johnny Cash song gets him so emotional

image.altText: Liam and Noel Gallagher of Oasis pose in jackets in front of a beige backdrop.

props.synopsis: The British band announce Sydney and Melbourne dates, marking first Australian tour since 2005.

title.children: Oasis announce Australian tour dates — and no dynamic pricing

image.altText: Partly smiling older woman with shaggy brown hair cut short, wears black and white striped tee and a necklace around her neck

props.synopsis: With its picturesque canals and waterfront homes, the Victorian holiday haven of Paynesville appears immune to the poverty that is quietly gripping the nation. But Foodbank Victoria says the reality is much harsher than it looks.

title.children: Hunger relief charity struggles as food insecurity becomes a 'disaster behind closed doors'

image.altText: a close up detailed shot of a pink flower

props.synopsis: The endangered Beadle's grevillea only grows in a few areas in the wild. After a harsh drought, the species is now thriving and the couple that saved it wants the plant safeguarded for generations to come.

title.children: Rare grevillea in full bloom after couple nurses plants through drought
